newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: S.Lanka leader to take devolution package to peopl.
newsitem.headline: S.Lanka leader to take devolution package to peopl.

text.p: Sri Lankan President Chandrika Kumaratunga plans to address a series of rallies across the country to explain her devolution proposals aimed at ending a 14-year-old ethnic war, officials said on Wednesday.

"We still feel that the level of awareness among the people is inadequate. The thrust of our campaign will be to give them a clearer notion of the constitution reforms," said Gamini Peiris, Minister of Justice and Constitutional Affairs.
The move was also seen as an attempt by Kumaratunga to drum up public support for her proposals and push the main opposition United National Party (UNP) into accepting them.

The proposals include constitutional reforms to devolve powers to new administrative units in a bid to partly meet the demand of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) rebels for a separate homeland in the India Ocean island's north and east.
"If there is a significant impact on the people, the UNP will have to take a definite stand, one way or the other," Peiris, the architect of the reforms, told Reuters.

The constitutional reform proposals are currently bogged in a parliamentary select committee where Kumaratunga's ruling People's Alliance is battling opposition parties, including the UNP, for a consensus.
UNP support is crucial as the government needs a two-thirds majority in parliament, where it has a slim majority, to pass the new constitution.
But UNP officials said the party would wait for a final package before giving its support, if at all.
"The government has not made up its mind on several issues. Let them tell us what they finally want and we will then look at the issues," a UNP lawmaker said.
Kumaratunga's meetings seem to be leading towards a non-binding referendum on the proposals, which if won by the government can put UNP in a spot and force its support.

Last month, Kumaratunga told a two-day meeting of her lawmakers that she could be forced to hold a nationwide non-binding referendum on the proposals ahead of taking them to parliament if the opposition's support was not forthcoming.
"We have not decided on a referendum, it is an alternative that is within the framework of the existing constitution," Peiris said.

Political analysts said a non-binding referendum prior to putting the proposals before parliament would have no significant legal stature, but the opposition would have to take a moral decision whether to oppose it if a majority of the nation votes in favour.
Once approved by parliament, the draft constitution will have to again face a national referendum for it to become legal.
While pursuing a political solution to the conflict, the government also seems firm in its resolve to continue the battle to neutralise the LTTE militarily and push them in a corner.
A military offensive in the north, launched in May to open a strategic northern highway and deal a blow to the LTTE's fighting machinery, has slowed after three major counter-attacks by the rebels.
The government says the death toll in the war against the LTTE is more than 50,000. The LTTE say the figure is higher.
